title-group.subtitle: A Review of Cardiac Arrest in Pregnancy

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Medicine, University of Alberta, Alberta, Canada
2Geisinger Health System, Gyn Obstetrics Maternal Fetal Medicine Danville, Danville, PA, USA
3Department of Medicine, Pulmonary and Critical Care Medicine, Warren Alpert Medical School of Brown University, Providence, RI, USA

author-notes.corresp: Ghada Bourjeily, Pulmonary and Critical Care Medicine, Warren Alpert Medical School of Brown University, The Miriam Hospital, 146 W River St Providence, RI 02903, USA.. Email: Ghada_bourjeily@brown.edu

abstract.p: Cardiac arrest is a rare occurrence in pregnancy and may be related to obstetric or medical causes. Pregnancy is associated with profound physiologic changes that prepare the gravida for the challenges of labor and delivery, and resuscitation of the pregnant patient needs to take these changes into consideration. Cardiac output and plasma volume increase in pregnancy and distribute differently with the uterine circulation receiving approximately 17% of the total cardiac output. On the other hand, cardiac output is sensitive to positional changes in the second half of pregnancy but may improve with a lateral tilt of the gravida. Both oxygen reserve and upper airway size decrease in pregnancy, leading to difficulties surrounding airway management. Changes in the volume of distribution, renal and hepatic clearance may impact drug effects and need to be recognized. This review will discuss an overview of pregnancy physiology that is relevant to cardiac resuscitation, detail the challenges in the various resuscitative steps including a synopsis on perimortem delivery, and describe obstetric and nonobstetric causes of mortality and cardiac arrest in pregnancy.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Cardiac arrest in pregnancy is a devastating event not only for the mother and fetus but for all involved in their care. The precise incidence of cardiac arrest in pregnancy is not known, however, it is estimated to occur in approximately 0.6 to 1 in 30 000 pregnancies,1–2 with the most recent UK confidential enquiry reporting an incidence of cardiac arrest in 1:20 000 pregnancies.3 Approximately 10% of maternal deaths present as cardiac arrest.4 While there has been increased awareness over the past decade regarding the need for certain modifications to the advanced cardiac life support (ACLS) protocol in pregnancy, recent studies suggest that clinicians' knowledge and performance remains suboptimal,5,6 even among those who specialize in maternal care—obstetricians, labor and delivery nurses, and anesthesiologists.6 Therefore, the purpose of this article is to provide a practical approach to cardiac arrest in the pregnant patients.

sec.title: Physiological Considerations
sec.p: In order to better comprehend the modifications necessary to the ACLS protocol in pregnant patients, it is important to understand the pertinent physiological changes in pregnancy (see summary Table 1 ) and the challenges of caring for both mother and fetus.

caption.p: Physiological Changes of Pregnancy Affecting ACLS Protocol.

tr.td: Increased minute ventilationDecreased FRCDecreased chest wall complianceIncreased oxygen consumption
Accelerated hypoxemiaIncreased difficulty with bag-mask ventilation
Increased cardiac output with 17% diversion to gravid uterus
Limited cardiac output with CPR (partially diverted to uterus)
Decreased preloadDecreased effectiveness of chest compressionsNeed to displace uterus
Benefit to maternal hemodynamics of fetal delivery
Delayed gastric emptyingIncreased intragastric pressureRelaxation of lower esophageal sphincter
Increased risk of aspiration, therefore importance of cricoid pressure and early intubation

fn.p: Abbreviations: ACLS, advanced cardiac life support; CPR, cardiopulmonary resuscitation; ETT, endotracheal tube; FRC, functional residual capacity.

sec.title: Respiratory Changes
sec.p: Pregnancy leads to significant changes in the respiratory system at many levels. Elevated levels of estrogens and increased plasma volume in pregnancy are associated with hyperemia of the mucosal tissues including the nasal cavity and the upper airway. These changes are more pronounced in preeclampsia, due to further reduction in oncotic pressure. Airway access and intubation may therefore be more difficult. Hyperemia and friability lead to increased risk of bleeding with introduction of gastric or tracheal tubes, which may limit visibility. This risk may be even higher in patients with complications such as thrombocytopenia occurring in association with preeclampsia or HELLP syndrome (hemolysis, elevated liver function tests, low platelets). In addition, pharyngolaryngeal and vocal cord edema may contribute to difficulties passing an endotracheal tube.7 With these physiological changes, the upper airway may be smaller in the third trimester in pregnant women without preeclampsia and women with preeclampsia than in the nonpregnant or postpartum woman.8 Intubation is therefore generally more difficult in the pregnant patient and a smaller Endotracheal tube (ETT) size may be necessary.9

The mechanics of respiration also are affected by hormonal and mechanical effects of pregnancy. Relaxin, a polypeptide hormone mediating pelvic ligament relaxation, may also be responsible for relaxation of the ligamentous attachment of the ribs,10 leading to a substantial increase in the subcostal angle that occurs even before the uterus enlarges. Subsequently, the gravid uterus causes the diaphragm to elevate about 4 cm, causing a decrease in chest compliance. Chest compliance may be decreased further by enlarged breasts. All of these changes lead to a reduction in the functional residual capacity (FRC) by approximately 20%, with an additional 25% drop in the supine position near term.11

Oxygen consumption and metabolic rate increase significantly in pregnancy due to the increased requirements of the fetus, placenta, and maternal organs and those needs are met with an increase in minute ventilation related to the stimulating properties of progesterone on the respiratory drive. Stimulation of the respiratory drive by progesterone also results in a reduction in arterial tension of carbon dioxide (PaCO2) and a mild respiratory alkalosis. Oxygen consumption increases further during labor and delivery. The combination of decreased FRC and increased oxygen consumption results in decreased oxygen reserve and can lead to a rapid decrease in oxygen saturation if alveolar hypoventilation occurs.12 In fact, arterial oxygen tension decreases and carbon dioxide increases significantly faster following obstructive apneas in sedated, paralyzed, mechanically ventilated and oxygenated pregnant women compared to nonpregnant controls.13 Intrapulmonary shunting is significantly elevated in late pregnancy in the supine position and measured at 13.9%.14 This measurement is 3 times higher than intrapulmonary shunting reported in the nonpregnant state. In addition, the fetus possesses many protective mechanisms. Fetal hemoglobin is less sensitive to the effects of 2,3 DPG than adult hemoglobin, given the lack of beta chains. Consequently, the fetal oxygen hemoglobin dissociation curve is shifted to the left, suggesting an increase in oxygen affinity. The fetus also appears to have an ability to shunt blood to vital organs and decrease oxygen consumption during periods of hypoxia. Despite of these protective mechanisms, placental health plays an important role in oxygen transport affecting umbilical oxygen uptake.15 Women with medical and obstetric disorders may have an abnormal placenta, and oxygen transport across a diseased placenta may be negatively affected. These factors should be considered in pregnant women who need sedation and paralysis prior to intubation and every effort made to appropriately ventilate and oxygenate a pregnant woman during resuscitation.

sec.title: Cardiovascular Changes
sec.p: As early as 6 weeks of gestation, there is a decrease in the systemic vascular resistance in pregnancy. This leads to decreased blood pressure (diastolic greater than systolic) and a widened pulse pressure. Heart rate increases by approximately 20% to 30% and blood volume increases by 30% to 50%.16,17 With the increased heart rate and stroke volume, cardiac output increases by 30% to 60%. Cardiac output is distributed differently in pregnancy with the uterine circulation receiving 17% of the total cardiac output.18–20 In the latter half of pregnancy, the gravid uterus causes aortocaval compression, particularly when supine, causing decreased preload, hypotension, and bradycardia in many patients. Because of this compression and subsequent slowed transit, intravenous (IV) lines in the lower extremities may be less effective than access above the diaphragm. The stroke volume and therefore cardiac output increase by 25% to 30% when the third-trimester patient is moved from supine to a lateral decubitus position.21 During labor and delivery, autotransfusion occurs where blood is shunted from the uterine circulation to the systemic circulation with about 500 cc of blood being pumped into the systemic circulation with every contraction, significantly increasing cardiac output.22,23

sec.title: Gastrointestinal Changes
sec.p: Hormonal changes of pregnancy lead to a decreased gastric pH and delayed gastric emptying. The gravid uterus also causes an increase in intragastric pressure leading to an increased risk of reflux. This increased risk is compounded by the hormonally related relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter. The above changes also result in decreased gastric transit time. The risk of aspiration of stomach contents is therefore significantly increased in the pregnant patient and may be worsened by air insufflations from bag–mask ventilation.

sec.title: Hematologic Changes
sec.p: Blood volume increases disproportionately compared to the increase in red cell mass in pregnancy. This results in a relative physiological anemia and reduced oncotic pressure. Profound reductions in oncotic pressure in situations, such as preeclampsia, may lead to intravascular volume depletion and extravascular overload. Physiologic anemia may often be further complicated by iron-deficiency anemia if there has been inadequate iron intake to meet fetal iron demands. In acute hypoxic events, oxygen delivery may be further reduced if significant anemia is present.

sec.title: ACLS Considerations in the Pregnant Patient
sec.p: Although preparations for the pregnant patient who presents to the emergency room may not be possible, recognizing pregnant patients at risk for arrest in the hospital may be key to the successful management of such patient. Given the need for multidisciplinary care, a list of providers needed in the event of a cardiac arrest may be prepared ahead of time to include the appropriate obstetrician, obstetric internist, pediatrician/neonatologist, anesthesiologist in addition to the code team/intensive care unit (ICU) team. Representatives of all disciplines should be notified at the onset of the arrest. Airway management kits should be readily available to include laryngeal mask airway or a difficult airway kit (Table 2 ). Cesarean delivery and neonatal resuscitation kits should also be kept at the bedside. Vaginal delivery is less likely to occur in the event of cardiac arrest unless the gravid arrests with a fully dilated cervix. The ACLS protocol for the pregnant cardiac arrest patient is similar to the nonpregnant patient, with a few exceptions (Table 2). The exceptions, however, can be the difference between a successful and a nonsuccessful resuscitation. In addition to the standard airway, breathing, circulation, defibrillation, and drugs (ABCDDs), delivery should be added (ABCDDD) as described below. As a general rule, a member of the team should be assigned to time the duration of the resuscitative efforts, as timing of perimortem delivery in relation to the initiation of the resuscitation is key to successful outcomes.

caption.p: Checklist for Pregnant Patients at Risk for Cardiac Arrest.

tr.td: □ Providers needed at time of arrest Code team: Intensivisit: Obstetrician: Pediatrician/neonatologist:
□ Periodic update to various resuscitative teams of patient’s condition

sec.p: Another consideration includes steroid administration to the mother to hasten fetal lung maturity and reduce comorbidities and even neonatal mortality. Although observations suggest that neonatal benefit begins to accrue within a few hours of glucocorticoid administration, liberal use of a single course of antenatal therapy is recommended in cases of impending delivery.

sec.title: Airway/Breathing
sec.p: Airway assessment should be the first step in the management of cardiac arrest as in the nonpregnant patient. In the case of acute airway obstruction with a foreign body, a Heimlich maneuver can be performed. However, applying forceful abdominal pressure may result in uterine rupture or may be less effective in late stages24 and the site of the thrusts may be moved upward to the chest, avoiding the sternum. The physiological changes in pregnancy necessitate certain alterations to the ACLS protocol (see Table 2), starting with the airway. Because of the accelerated hypoxemia of pregnancy following apneas, immediate mask ventilation with 100% oxygen is necessary. However, bag–mask ventilation will exacerbate the risk of aspiration and therefore it is necessary to apply cricoid pressure as soon as possible, and early intubation is recommended.9

Intubation of the pregnant patient can, however, be difficult and failed intubations are 8 times more likely to occur in pregnancy compared to the general surgical population.25 Therefore, airway intubation should be undertaken by the most experienced provider available. A smaller sized ETT is recommended, given the laryngeal edema and increased friability of the upper airway mucosa in pregnancy.11 In the event that intubation fails, an alternative airway device, such as a supraglottic airway device or combitube, should be used in conjunction with cricoid pressure. Laryngeal mask airways have been found to be lifesaving rescue devices in cases of failed intubation in obstetric patients7 and can be used until an alternative airway device (such as a combitube) can be placed.11 If available, videolaryngoscopy should be utilized as it decreases the risk of failed intubation in these patients by providing enhanced glottic view.26 Once an airway has been established, oxygenation with 100% oxygen must be continued.

sec.title: Circulation
sec.p: There is controversy in the literature as to the actual benefit of such interventions. Some studies have found improvement in maternal hemodynamics with left lateral tilt,28,29 while others have failed to show significant benefit,30,31 especially when compared with manual displacement of the uterus.32 However, many of these studies31–33 tilted the patient only 10 to 20° and therefore may underestimate the benefit expected at 27°. Manual displacement may be as effective as physical tilt,32 however, to date, the study sizes and variability in measurements make it difficult to conclude with certainty the most advantageous intervention.34 Given that CPR is much more easily performed in the supine position and that adequate wedges are not commonly available, it does not seem unreasonable to begin with manual leftward uterine displacement and proceed to a 27° wedge if CPR is ineffective.

The most advantageous hand placement for chest compressions in CPR in a pregnant patient is unknown. However, given the elevated diaphragm and abdominal contents caused by the gravid uterus, it is not unreasonable to consider slightly superior hand positioning than normal as recommended by the 2005 American Heart Association (AHA) guidelines35 and the Circulation 2010 guidelines.9

sec.title: Defibrillation
sec.p: There have been very few studies looking at defibrillation in cardiac arrest in pregnancy. Nanson et al, using women as their own controls, looked at transthoracic impedance (measured by a defibrillator) in 45 women at term and in 42 of them at 6 to 8 weeks of postpartum.36 There was no significant difference in mean transthoracic impedance noted before or after delivery. The risk of defibrillation to the fetus is felt to be small,37 especially if all internal and external fetal monitors are removed, and it is therefore recommended to remove fetal monitors and defibrillate as per usual protocol.9

sec.title: Drugs
sec.p: In pregnancy, there is an increased glomerular filtration rate (GFR) and altered pharmacokinetics of many medications related to a differing volume of distribution, in addition to decreased protein binding and increased renal clearance. Despite of the above-mentioned physiologic changes, there have been no studies evaluating medication dosing and pharmacokinetics during resuscitation in pregnancy and current recommendations continue to suggest following the current adult ACLS medication guidelines.9

However, some alterations may need to be considered. For example, there is a 4-fold increase in the metabolic clearance of vasopressin in the second half of pregnancy related to increased vasopressinase activity,38–40 which may mean that higher doses of vasopressin might be needed in order to achieve an adequate, therapeutic effect. This, unfortunately, has not been studied to date.

While long-term use of amiodarone in pregnancy may increase the risk of fetal goiter, transient hypothyroidism, and rarely mental delay, there are no data evaluating such complications in women treated acutely for life-threatening arrhythmias.41,42 In such cases, benefit of the drug should be weighed against the possible risk and the presence of equally effective, alternative drugs. Lidocaine has been safely used to treat maternal ventricular arrhythmias without adverse fetal outcomes.43 Although long-standing procainamide use has been associated with increased incidence of maternal antinuclear antibodies and lupus-like syndrome in pregnancy, fetal data are reassuring.44,45 The use of calcium channel blockers for rhythm and rate control appears to be safe in pregnancy with little fetal effect.46,47 Beta-blocker use in pregnancy may increase the risk of fetal bradycardia and low birth weight.48,49 The latter may be due to compromise of placental hemodynamics50 (especially noted with atenolol).51,52 However, the effects on birth weight may be related to excess blood pressure control—as evidenced by the lack of difference in small-for-gestational-age infants noted in patients treated with methyldopa compared to beta-blockers53—rather than a direct medication effect, a question that the Control of Hypertension in Pregnancy (CHIPS) trial (currently underway) will hopefully help answer.53

Medications used for sedation (eg, fentanyl and midazolam) appear to be safe in pregnancy. Although fentanyl does cross the placenta freely, the drug does not appear to have any adverse neonatal effects.54 While diazepam may increase the risk of congenital anomalies as well as the “floppy infant syndrome,” midazolam appears to have less fetal effects55 and is therefore the preferred benzodiazepine. It is important to keep in mind that these medications may have a depressive effect on the newborn’s respiratory drive and tone if administered close to delivery and the pediatricians should be notified of drugs received during resuscitation.

In addition, caution should be used with administration of sodium bicarbonate in pregnancy as rapid correction of maternal acidosis might decrease the patients' compensatory hyperventilation, thereby causing normalization of maternal PaCO2 and subsequent increase in fetal PaCO2 and fetal acidosis.12,56 In addition, the rate of transfer of ions across the placenta is not well studied but is believed to occur slowly, suggesting that the administration of bicarbonate may not be adequate to correct fetal acidosis. In addition, alpha-adrenergic agents in combination with alpha- and beta-agonists might produce uteroplacental vasoconstriction, leading to decreased fetal oxygenation and increased fetal hypercarbia.24 In situations of hypotension related to the administration of regional anesthesia, most commonly used drugs include phenylephrine and ephedrine.57 Recent reports show that when compared to phenylephrine infusion at cesarean section, ephedrine is associated with higher heart rate, more maternal nausea and vomiting as well as a higher incidence of fetal acidosis but comparable effects on blood pressure.58 In addition, a recent meta-analysis comparing the two drugs reported similar findings including a higher fetal pH associated with phenylephrine.59 However, when other agents are thought to be more beneficial in the treatment of hypotension related to other causes, the clinician should not hesitate to use the drugs with the most benefit. Other interventions to salvage the fetus can then be considered.

sec.title: Delivery
sec.p: Perimortem delivery has been increasingly recognized as an important step in the ACLS protocol in the pregnant patient. The concept, however, is not new. Roman Law established in c715 BC, “Lex Regis de Inferendo Mortus” required surgical delivery of fetuses if the woman were to die in pregnancy, a practice that continued throughout the Middle Ages for religious reasons.60 Katz et al in 1986 derived a 4-minute rule for cardiac arrest–initiation of cesarean section at 4 minutes, delivery of infant at 5 minutes—based on a physiological understanding of pregnancy and the knowledge that irreversible brain damage from anoxia occurs within 4 to 6 minutes of inadequate cerebral perfusion.61 Their finding that infant survival was significantly better if the infant was delivered within 5 minutes of maternal death also supported this rule. Many reports have since supported this rule.62–65

The gestational age at which perimortem cesarean section should be performed is not well established, but it is likely the most important predictor of successful neonatal outcomes. In the Confidential Enquiry into Maternal and Child Health (CEMACH) 2003-2005 report,3 the rate of live births increased as gestational age increased, with fetal survival as early as 24 to 27 weeks (5 of 13 cases). When considering a perimortem cesarean section, the clinician should contemplate both maternal and fetal effects of delivery. From a maternal physiological standpoint, one might not expect the maternal hemodynamics to be significantly affected by a fetus less than 24 weeks of gestation and resuscitation in this case should focus on maternal well-being. However, theoretically, a fundal height extending above the umbilicus (an equivalent of 20 weeks) could indicate aortocaval compression, and it might be reasonable to perform perimortem cesarean section in these patients regardless of gestational age,66 while understanding that the fetus is unlikely to survive before 24 weeks. The obstetric team can help make that decision. From a fetal physiological standpoint, a fetus is viable at 24 weeks—but recent reports have shown viability as early as 23 weeks due to recent technological advances67,68—and should be delivered if resuscitation is believed to extend beyond 5 minutes. These facts should allow for variations in neonatal resuscitative efforts depending on institutional capabilities and resources where some institutions may not be able to resuscitate a neonate born prior to 32 weeks of gestation. Gestational age in most cases may be estimated based on the date of last menstrual period, fundal height, or prior ultrasounds. However, a quick ultrasound may help determine approximate gestational age to determine fetal viability in cases where the mother is not known to the providers. Ultrasounds may also help determine whether the fetus is dead or alive; in the former case, the decision to deliver would then only take into account the maternal status. Delivery needs to be performed at the bedside and patients would not need to be transferred to the operating room.

While perimortem cesarean sections were initially thought to benefit only the fetus, it is now recognized to be of considerable maternal benefit. Unfortunately, however, the incidence of perimortem cesarean section, and of maternal survival, is not known. Maternal benefit from perimortem delivery is thought to be a result of aortocaval compression relief leading to improved venous return and cardiac output and redistribution of cardiac output with a reduction in the flow to the uterus. Delivery of the fetus may also make chest compressions more effective by improving compliance, respiratory mechanics, and possibly oxygenation. Katz et al did a follow-up study in 2005, identifying 38 cases of perimortem delivery.69 Of the 38 cases, 14 women had conditions from which they were unlikely to survive (eg, extensive injury from gunshot wounds). However, 12 women had a dramatic improvement with cesarean section, 2 women had nonspecific improvements, and 2 had return of pulse but with unstable blood pressures. The maternal status following cesarean section was not mentioned in the remaining patients. A recent study from the Netherlands looked at perimortem cesarean section over 15 years.70 Out of 55 women who underwent CPR, 12 had a perimortem cesarean section, none of which occurred within the 5-minute time period. Of the 4 cases done within 5 to 15 minutes (3 in hospital and 1 out of hospital), there were 2 maternal survivals. One of these survivors, who had a significant medical history of hypertension and diabetes and whose cause of cardiac arrest was preeclampsia with pulmonary edema, was noted at 2 months post-arrest to have vascular dementia with delirium and cognitive impairment. The remaining 8 cases were performed in the range of 15 to 45 minutes, with fatal maternal outcomes in all cases. Randomized controlled trials regarding the timing of delivery would help answer this question more definitively but are hard to justify from an ethical point of view.

The fetal benefits of cesarean section are more fully documented. From a physiological standpoint, it is felt that a fetus can survive for up to 10 minutes in the face of asphyxia.22 In their 2005 study, Katz et al documented 38 perimortem deliveries, 28 of which resulted in 34 live births (including multiple gestations). Of these, 1 twin went on to die from an anoxic brain injury. Among the surviving infants, the rate of normal infants was higher if delivery occurred within 5 minutes of maternal arrest, although there were 4 out of 7 normal infants reported with perimortem delivery exceeding 15 minutes. In the Netherlands study, there were 3 neonates (out of 4 cases) delivered within 5 to 15 minutes of maternal cardiac arrest. Of these 3 neonates there were no long-term follow-up results, although 2 were reported to be healthy at the time of discharge from the hospital. Of the 8 perimortem deliveries performed from 15 to 45 minutes post-arrest, there were 2 neonatal survivors, 1 reported as healthy, the other had neurological damage. There have even been case reports of fetal survival (without neurological damage) after 30 to 45 minutes of maternal death.71,72 The largest report of neonatal survival comes from CEMACH 2003-2005,3 which reports 20 of 52 infants delivered by perimortem delivery surviving. Factors that improve infant survival rates include proximity to an operating room or delivery suite,3 advanced gestational age (preferably greater than 35 weeks gestation),3,60 absence of chronic maternal illness,60 and duration of time between cardiac arrest and infant delivery.

Although perimortem delivery is recommended within 5 minutes of cardiac arrest, it is difficult to meet these standards.3,69,70 Techniques to improve timeliness of delivery include initiating a protocol to deliver by 1 minute,56 having a dedicated perimortem cesarean section equipment pack available on crash carts in units caring for obstetric patients,73,74 educational programs (especially with simulation training),6,70,73,75 and regular drills.60 Cesarean delivery should be done via the surgical technique that the operator is most comfortable with (midline or Pfannenstiel).60 Vaginal delivery assisted with forceps or vacuum devices is rarely acceptable during a cardiac arrest.6 The current guidelines recommend perimortem delivery even if it will not be completed within the 5-minute window.9

sec.title: Post-Arrest Care
sec.p: Pregnant women have been excluded from the main trials looking at therapeutic hypothermia. However, Rittenberger et al report a case of a patient with a cardiac arrest at 13 weeks of gestation who was resuscitated and underwent therapeutic hypothermia and was subsequently able to deliver a healthy baby at term.76 The current recommendations from the AHA are therefore to consider hypothermia based on nonpregnant recommendations but to consider continuous fetal monitoring throughout the treatment.9

sec.title: Etiology of Cardiac Arrest in Pregnancy
sec.p: Once the initial ACLS has been initiated, the next step toward appropriate management of any cardiac arrest is an understanding of the possible etiologies. The major causes of maternal mortality in pregnancy can be divided into 2 categories: (1) obstetric (Direct) and (2) nonobstetric (indirect). These conditions are also the most likely to cause a cardiac arrest in pregnancy and many have specific treatment interventions.

sec.title: Obstetric (Direct) Causes
sec.p: An obstetric (direct) cause of death is one that occurs during the antenatal, intrapartum, or postpartum period resulting from a condition or complication that is unique to pregnancy or from an intervention related to pregnancy. As can be seen in Table 3 , in the developed world, venous thromboembolism is a common cause of maternal mortality.3,77 In a patient suspected to have a pulmonary embolism, CPR can cause liver lacerations if the liver is swollen from venous congestion,78 and in such cases, superior hand placement for CPR should be considered. If pulmonary embolism is the suspected cause of cardiac arrest, thrombolysis should be administered according to the standard (nonpregnant) cardiac arrest protocol.9 Pulmonary embolectomy has also been used successfully for massive pulmonary embolism following cesarean section.78

caption.p: Modifications to Standard ACLS Protocol Necessary in Pregnant Patients.

tr.td: Early intubationCricoid pressure until intubation achieved
Leftward displacement of the uterus (manual or by use of a wedge at 27°)Caudal placement of hands for CPR
Standard ACLS protocolEnsure removal of fetal monitors
Standard ACLS dosesCaution with sodium bicarbonateCaution with alpha-adrenergic agents
Initiate perimortem delivery at 4 minutes if resuscitation unsuccessfulAlert appropriate neonatologist and obstetrician of arrest as soon as cardiac arrest occurs

sec.title: Preeclampsia/eclampsia
sec.p: Preeclampsia/eclampsia is the second most common cause of maternal death.3,77 One possible etiology for this is that patients with preeclampsia are more susceptible to cerebrovascular accidents related to hypertension due to the endothelial dysfunction occurring in preeclampsia. The cerebrovascular accidents may then lead to cardiac arrest.56 Because preeclampsia may result in intravascular volume depletion, CPR is even less likely to provide significant cardiac output and therefore aggressive volume resuscitation should be considered.24,56 Patients with preeclampsia are treated with magnesium sulfate, however, magnesium toxicity (with levels of 6-10 mmol/L, or lower in patients with renal failure) can cause cardiac arrest,9,73 although no incidence for magnesium-related cardiac arrests was reported in CEMACH. Patients who have received magnesium sulfate pre-arrest should be reversed with calcium9 (calcium gluconate 30 ml in 10% solution IV or intraosseous [IO] or calcium chloride 10 mL in 10% solution IV/IO route) should be given.9

sec.title: Sepsis
sec.p: Sepsis remains a cause of maternal mortality. While the majority of cases appear to be puerperal sepsis77 or genital tract sepsis,3 Lemierre syndrome, although uncommon, can increase the risk of cardiac tamponade in the postpartum period, thereby leading to cardiac arrest.24

sec.title: Anaphylactoid syndrome in pregnancy
sec.p: Although thought generally to be rare, the incidence of anaphylactoid syndrome in pregnancy—previously known as amniotic fluid embolism—related maternal mortality has increased.3 Because this disorder is difficult to diagnose and confirm, the incidence of anaphylactoid syndrome is not well known. However, it is estimated to occur in 1/8000 to 80 000 pregnancies and carries a mortality rate of 50% to 80%, with up to 87% of these cases involving a cardiac arrest.56

sec.title: Hemorrhage
sec.p: The most common cause of maternal mortality worldwide, peripartum hemorrhage remains an important cause of maternal mortality even in the developed world. The maternal hemorrhage may be a result of placental abruption, placenta previa, placenta accreta, uterine atony, disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), or a coagulation defect, and such causes must always be considered in the pregnant patient with a cardiovascular collapse.

sec.title: Anesthesia
sec.p: Interestingly, a common cause of maternal mortality in the developed world, reported in the United States,79 Canada,77 and the United Kingdom,3 is anesthesia. The maternal mortality rate from general anesthesia may be as high as 1/20 000 maternities.3 These generally resulted from difficult or failed intubations, or a failure to oxygenate the patient. This is particularly true in obese patients especially in the presence of any underlying respiratory disease.80 Neural axial blockade is also associated with an increased risk of cardiac arrest. In the nonobstetric healthy population, approximately 2.9/10000 patients receiving spinal anesthesia have a cardiac arrest, with 54% of these arrests being attributed directly to the anesthesia (usually resulting from a high sympathectomy).80

One possible cause of spinal- or epidural-related cardiac arrest may be attributed to vagal-linked reflexes with anesthesia-related inhibition of sympathetic efferents, leading to vasodilatation and redistribution of blood to the splanchnic beds and lower extremities, in turn leading to decreased venous return and thereby decreased preload leading to vagal stimulation.7 This may have an even more important role in those who did not receive volume preloading, or those who have existing decreased preload (eg, from hemorrhage).7 The level of anesthesia may also play a role. It is possible to have a sympathetic blockage at a higher level than the sensory level, which could lead to blockade of the T1-T4 cardiac accelerator fibers in cases of “high” anesthesia.7 A recent prospective multicenter study from Thailand looking at all cases of cardiac arrest after spinal anesthesia (including nonpregnant patients) found an incidence of cardiac arrest during spinal anesthesia of 2.73/10 000 patients (95% CI, 1.14-4.34), with a mortality rate of 90%.81 Of the patients who were pregnant, there was an incidence of cardiac arrests during spinal anesthesia of 4.43 /10000 (95% CI 0.5-8.3), with a mortality rate of 80%. Of the 5 obstetric cases included in the study, 2 had a cardiac arrest after significant bleeding from uterine atony, 1 had received repeated intrathecal injections of 10 mg bupivacaine because of inadequate analgesia, and 1 had a cardiac arrest after 5 minutes with a dermatome level not recorded. For at least 2 of these patients, therefore, the cause of the cardiac arrest may not have been the anesthesia itself.

In cases of cardiac arrest related to anesthesia, resuscitation may be improved if patients are treated with vasopressin7 rather than epinephrine alone. However, there is also a suggestion that early epinephrine may be useful as patients with spinal/epidural anesthesia do not have the expected catecholamine release during cardiac arrest.80 Other interventions include amiodarone if there is a presumed bupivacaine-induced ventricular dysrhythmia82 and lipid emulsions. The latter may provide an alternative-binding source for lipid-soluble local anesthetics, thereby attenuating the toxicity of the anesthetic.82 A proposed protocol is outlined by Suresh et al.82

sec.title: Other
sec.p: Other less common obstetrical causes include peripartum cardiomyopathy56,77 and prostaglandin use.83 The latter has been reported to cause hypotension, bradycardia, ventricular arrhythmias, myocardial infarctions, coronary vasospasm, and cardiac arrest.83

sec.title: Nonobstetric (Indirect) Causes
sec.p: A nonobstetric or indirect cause of maternal mortality is one that results from a preexisting disease or a medical disorder that arises in pregnancy that is exacerbated by but not due to pregnancy.

sec.title: Cardiovascular disease
sec.p: In recent years, cardiovascular disease has surpassed trauma as the leading nonobstetric cause of maternal mortality.3 Of the cardiovascular causes of maternal death, myocardial infarction was the most common. Although this is likely related to the increasing maternal age noted in developed nations as well as the increased obesity rate, pregnancy itself may also play a role. This is supported by the finding that myocardial infarctions in pregnancy are 3 to 4 times more common than those in nonpregnant women of childbearing age.84 The intervention of choice in cases of myocardial infarction in pregnancy is primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI).9,85

The second most common cardiovascular cause of death is aortic dissection.3 This risk is especially increased in women with Marfan syndrome, coarctation of the aorta, or bicuspid aortic valve. Congenital heart disease, especially in the presence of pulmonary hypertension, is the third most common etiology.3 These risks are generally highest in the third trimester and puerperal period. Arrythmogenic conditions such as the long-QT syndrome also increase the risk of peripartum cardiac arrest. These occur most commonly in the postpartum time period, generally after the first 24 hours postpartum,86 with controversy as to whether or not an increased risk exists during pregnancy.86–88

caption.p: Direct Causes of Maternal Mortality Based on the UK Confidential Enquiry (CEMEACH) 2003-2005.
Indirect Causes of Maternal Mortality Based on the UK Confidential Enquiry (CEMACH) 2003-2005.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: All persons involved in the care of pregnant women should be trained in ACLS, with a particular emphasis on the adjustments needed for pregnant women. The key alterations to the ACLS protocol include early intubation, superior hand placement for CPR, left lateral displacement of the uterus, obtain IV access above the diaphragm, caution with sodium bicarbonate, and initiation of cesarean section by 4 minutes if the fundal height is at or above the umbilicus. The use of these techniques will increase the success rate of ACLS in pregnant women as well as improve fetal outcomes. In order to comply with these standards, education and protocols in all hospitals caring for pregnant women needs to be instituted and regular drills and simulation protocols may help with the maintenance of these skills.

ack.title: Acknowledgments
ack.p: Beth Hott and Gwen LaRiviere for their assistance with manuscript preparation, and Sean Thomas for his help with the illustration.
